article.title: Dolly_%28sheep%29

template.arg: [[National Museum of Scotland]] (remains on display). Currently on exhibition at [[Edinburgh University Library]]{{cite web |url
First mammal to be cloned from an adult somatic cell
Six lambs (Bonnie; twins Sally and Rosie; triplets Lucy, Darcy and Cotton)

article.paragraph: Dolly(5 July 1996 14 February 2003) was a femaledomestic sheep, and the firstanimalto becloningclonedfrom an adultsomatic cell, using the process ofnuclear transfer.Cite journalMcLaren ACloning: pathways to a pluripotent futureScience28854721775–8020001087769810.1126/science.288.5472.1775Cite journal4Wilmut ISchnieke AEMcWhir JKind AJCampbell KHViable offspring derived from fetal and adult mammalian cellsNature3856619810–31997903991110.1038/385810a01997Natur.385..810WShe was cloned byIan Wilmut,Keith Campbell (biologist)Keith Campbelland colleagues at theRoslin Institute, part of theUniversity of Edinburgh, Scotland, and the biotechnology company PPL Therapeutics, based nearEdinburgh. The funding for Dolly's cloning was provided by PPL Therapeutics and the Ministry of Agriculture.Cite journal10.1080/00141844.1999.9981606Why dolly matters: Kinship, culture and cloningEthnos643–43011999EdwardsJ.She was born on 5 July 1996 and died from a progressive lung disease 5 months before her seventh birthday."Dolly the sheep clone dies young". BBC News. 14 February 2003She has been called "the world's most famous sheep" by sources includingBBC NewsandScientific American.Cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/353617.stmIs Dolly old before her time?27 May 1999[[BBC News]]4 October 2009LondonCite newshttp://www.sciam.com/article.cfm?idNo More Cloning AroundLehrmanSallyJuly 2008[[Scientific American]]21 September 2008

The cell used as the donor for the cloning of Dolly was taken from amammary gland, and the production of a healthy clone therefore proved that a cell taken from a specific part of the body could recreate a whole individual. On Dolly's name, Wilmut stated "Dolly is derived from a mammary gland cell and we couldn't think of a more impressive pair of glands thanDolly Parton's".cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/february/22/newsid_4245000/4245877.stmBBC News1997: Dolly the sheep is cloned22 February 1997
article.heading: Birth
article.paragraph: Dolly was born on 5 July 1996 and had three mothers (one provided the egg, another the DNA and a third carried the cloned embryo to term).cite journalWilliams2003N.Death of Dolly marks cloning milestoneCurrent Biology136209–2101264613910.1016/S0960-9822(03)00148-9She was created using the technique ofsomatic cell nuclear transfer, where thecell nucleusfrom an adult cell is transferred into an unfertilizedoocyte(developing egg cell) that has had its cell nucleus removed. The hybrid cell is then stimulated to divide by an electric shock, and when it develops into ablastocystit is implanted in a surrogate mother.Cite journalCampbell KHMcWhir JRitchie WAWilmut ISheep cloned by nuclear transfer from a cultured cell lineNature380656964–61996859890610.1038/380064a01996Natur.380...64CDolly was the first clone produced from a cell taken from an adult mammal. The production of Dolly showed that genes in the nucleus of such a maturecellular differentiationdifferentiatedsomatic cell are still capable of reverting to an embryonicTotipotencytotipotentstate, creating a cell that can then go on to develop into any part of an animal.Cite journalNiemann HTian XCKing WALee RSEpigenetic reprogramming in embryonic and foetal development upon somatic cell nuclear transfer cloningReproduction1352151–63February 20081823904610.1530/REP-07-0397Dolly's existence was announced to the public on 22 February 1997.It gained much attention in the media. A commercial with Scottish scientists playing with sheep was aired on TV, and a special report in TIME Magazine featured Dolly the sheep.Sciencefeatured Dolly as the breakthrough of the year. Even though Dolly was not the first animal to be cloned, she gained this attention in the media because she was the first to be cloned from an adult cell.cite journalMcKinnell, Robert G.Di Berardino, Marie A.The Biology of Cloning: History and RationaleBioscience4911875–885November 199910.2307/13136471313647
article.heading: Life
article.paragraph: File:Dolly clone.svgthumbright250pxThecloningprocess that produced DollyDolly lived her entire life at theRoslin InstituteinEdinburgh. There she was bred with aWelsh Mountain sheepWelsh Mountain ramand produced six lambs in total. Her first lamb, named Bonnie, was born in April 1998.The next year Dolly produced twin lambs Sally and Rosie, and she gave birth to triplets Lucy, Darcy and Cotton in the year after that.Dolly's family. Roslin InstituteIn late 2001, at the age of four, Dolly developedarthritisand began to walk stiffly. This was treated withanti-inflammatorydrugs.Dolly's arthritis. Roslin Institute, Accessed 21 February 2008
article.heading: Death
article.paragraph: On 14 February 2003, Dolly wasAnimal euthanasiaeuthanisedbecause she had a progressive lung disease and severe arthritis.Dolly's final illnessRoslin Institute, Accessed 21 February 2008Cached versionwaybackhttp://www.roslin.ac.uk/publicInterest/DollyFinalIilness.php20121030120853AFinnish Dorset (sheep)Finn Dorsetsuch as Dolly has a life expectancy of around 11 to 12 years, but Dolly lived to be 6.5 years old. A post-mortem examination showed she had a form of lung cancer calledJaagsiekte,Bridget M. KuehnGoodbye, Dolly; first cloned sheep dies at six years oldAmerican Veterinary Medical Association, 15 April 2003which is a fairly common disease of sheep and is caused by theretrovirusJSRV.Cite journalPalmarini MA Veterinary Twist on Pathogen BiologyPLoS Pathog.32e12200717319740http://pathogens.plosjournals.org/perlserv/?request10.1371/journal.ppat.00300121803002Roslin scientists stated that they did not think there was a connection with Dolly being a clone, and that other sheep in the same flock had died of the same disease.Such lung diseases are a particular danger for sheep kept indoors, and Dolly had to sleep inside for security reasons.

Some in the press speculated that a contributing factor to Dolly's death was that she could have been born with a genetic age of six years, the same age as the sheep from which she was cloned.One basis for this idea was the finding that Dolly'stelomereswere short, which is typically a result of theageingprocess.Cite journalShiels PGKind AJCampbell KHAnalysis of telomere length in Dolly, a sheep derived by nuclear transferCloning12119–2519991621883710.1089/15204559950020003etalCite journalShiels PGKind AJCampbell KHAnalysis of telomere lengths in cloned sheepNature3996734316–719991036057010.1038/205801999Natur.399..316HetalThe Roslin Institute have stated that intensive health screening did not reveal any abnormalities in Dolly that could have come from advanced aging.Was Dolly already 'old' at birth?Roslin Institute, Accessed 4 April 2010
article.heading: Legacy
article.paragraph: After cloning was successfully demonstrated through the production of Dolly, many other large mammals were cloned, includingpigs,Cite journalGrishamJulieNature BiotechnologyPigs cloned for first time18436510.1038/74335April 2000http://www.nature.com/nbt/journal/v18/n4/full/nbt0400_365b.htmlShukman, David (14 January 2014)China cloning on an 'industrial scale'BBC News Science and Environment, Retrieved 14 January 2014deer,Cite newshttp://www.innovations-report.de/html/berichte/biowissenschaften_chemie/bericht-24409.htmlTexas A&M scientists clone world’s first deer1 January 200723 December 2003Innovations Reporthorsesandbulls.cite webLozanoJuan A.A&M Cloning project raises questions stillBryan-College Station Eagle27 June 2005http://www.theeagle.com/stories/062705/am_20050627004.php30 April 2007The attempt to cloneargali(mountain sheep) did not produce viable embryos. The attempt to clone abantengbull was more successful, as were the attempts to clonemouflon(a form of wild sheep), both resulting in viable offspring.Cite newsEndangered sheep clonedhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/1573309.stm12 November 2007BBC News1 October 2001LondonThe reprogramming process cells need to go through during cloning is not perfect and embryos produced by nuclear transfer often show abnormal development.Cite journalJaenisch RHochedlinger KEggan KNuclear cloning, epigenetic reprogramming and cellular differentiationNovartis Found. Symp.265107–18; discussion 118–2820051605025310.1002/0470091452.ch9Novartis Foundation Symposia978-0-470-09145-6Cite journalRideout WMEggan KJaenisch RNuclear cloning and epigenetic reprogramming of the genomeScience29355321093–8August 20011149858010.1126/science.1063206Making cloned mammals was highly inefficient (Dolly was the only lamb that survived to adulthood from 277 attempts although by 2014 Chinese scientists were reported to have 7080% success rates cloning pigs.) Wilmut, who led the team that created Dolly, announced in 2007 that the nuclear transfer technique may never be sufficiently efficient for use in humans.Roger Highfield"Dolly creator Prof Ian Wilmut shuns cloning".Daily Telegraph16 November 2007

Cloning may have uses in preserving endangered species and may become a viable tool for revivingExtinctionextinct species.Cite journalTrounson AOFuture and applications of cloningMethods Mol. Biol.348319–32200616988390http://biomed.humanapress.com/ChapterDetail.pasp?medline10.1007/978-1-59745-154-3_22Methods in Molecular Biology978-1-58829-280-3In January 2009, scientists from the Centre of Food Technology and Research of Aragon, in northern Spain announced the cloning of thePyrenean ibex, a form of wild mountain goat, which was officially declared extinct in 2000. Although the newborn ibex died shortly after birth due to physical defects in its lungs it is the first time an extinct animal has been cloned, and may open doors for saving endangered and newly extinct species by resurrecting them from frozen tissue.Cite newsExtinct ibex is resurrected by cloninghttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/science-news/4409958/Extinct-ibex-is-resurrected-by-cloning.html1 February 2009The TelegraphLondonRichardGrayRogerDobson31 January 2009Jabr, Ferris (11 March 2013)Will Cloning Ever Save Endangered Animals?Scientific American, Retrieved 15 January 2014
